text:
INTERVIEWER: If I'm
a customer I come in

and I eat at Nando's, what are
the ways in which you actually

concretely really
inspire people?

ROBERT BROZIN: So the first
way we look at it is we say,

great brands are built
from the inside out.

So we look at our
people, and we say

that for us to inspire
you as a customer,
we need inspired people.

Because if our people aren't
inspired, there's no ways
they're going to inspire you.

So we need to really
work with our people.

And the kind of golden law that
I say, if you had say to me,

"what's the golden
law of Nando's?"

It's treat people the way
you would want to be treated.

And that to me is the
essence of Nando's.
And we're hiring diverse people.

We're hiring people that we
come from humble beginnings,

so we don't mind that you
come from humble beginnings.

So we take people from
the humblest of beginnings

or the roughest neighborhoods
or perceived the people

coming from say, the
journeys that haven't been as
easy as a lot of other people.
We love that.
They for us are people that--

I love when those people
come into the business
because we give them dignity.

We give people a chance to
actually prove themselves
as an individual.
We love individuals.

We love people coming and
providing their own little

individual magic
because ultimately,

it's individuals that
have created Nando's.

It's not through
a business plan.

It's not through some
clever business schools.

It's really being created by
individuals that have come in

and added their touch
into what we've done.

So it's an individual
brand and we said,

we're only as good as
all of us together.
So that's the starting point.

And so you start
respecting people.

And if you can build a
culture of diversity,

a culture of respect, a culture
of treating people right,

treating people with
dignity, with the kind
of sense of understanding.

That if you're religious, you
can come in with that headgear.

If you need to take
certain holidays,

you take those holidays, we
understand those holidays.

It's not something that
we say, if you're a Muslim

or you're a Jew, we understand
that you might not--

if you're going
to a dinner party

with Nando's and you don't
want to eat, that's fine.

We understand the sensitivities
of different religions
and we actually respect it.

As shareholders, big
time, we respect it

and we expect our
business to do that.

So that then manifests
itself in the way

that you as a customer coming to
Nando's are going to be served.

So that if you come into
a Nando's restaurant

where the people are
happy, people are inspired,

they're motivated, and they've
come from diverse backgrounds,

you're going to come to
Nando's and your experience

at Nando's is going to
be magical, hopefully,

because the guy that's
cooking the chickens

is also-- we've got a thing
on at the moment, tomorrow.
Starts tomorrow in Ireland.

It's called the World
Grillers Championships.

And we take grillers, the
guy that cook the chickens,

we take them from
around the world.

We run regional competitions,
then country competitions,

and we have a world champion
grilling competition
in different locations.

Last year was Australia,
this year is Ireland,
next year is Mauritius.

And you take guys that have
never had passports before,

from all over the
world, they come

and they enter into
this competition.
It only affects--

I think there's something
like 45 grillers that

are going in the
world of Nando's

but the effort,
the kind of respect

that this competition gets from
a worldwide-- because you can

come from Khayelitsha in Cape
Town and end up in Ireland,

or from the South Side of
Chicago and you're in Ireland.

You have to get your passport
and go off to Ireland and such.

Universal, Malaysia, Singapore,
the country winners come in
and they compete.

And that's one
element of so much

that we do within
the organization.
It's our approach to do things.

It's the way we look
at our art, it's

the way we look at our
design of our furniture,

it's the way we look at just so
many different little programs

that when you join Nando's and
you understand the essence,

it's not one thing
it's a combination
of a whole lot of things.

But there's a safety
that you come in here

and if you're slightly
different, you're OK.

If you're a refugee,
we welcome you in.
But you have to work.

It's not like you're coming
in and you can freestyle
and end up doing nothing.

You'll be caught out very
quickly and you'll go.
There is accountability.
The KPIs, you have to deliver.

Certainly, at restaurant
levels, very strong KPIs.

But there's a strong,
fun element to those too,
to everything as well.

Conferences, and Christmas
parties, and family events,

and there's so many different--
the managers of each

of the restaurants, the Patraos,
are encouraged to understand

lots of issues
around mental health,

understand issues
around family wellness,

And so there's got
to be a sensitivity.

It's not one thing, it's
a whole lot of things.

It's like a philosophy
of how we're doing it.

And we're getting better
and better and better at it.
It's also a journey.
We're learning.
